texts.shortText: Previously incorrectly identified as P. variegata (which is a valid species, but occurs in Chile).

Robust, firm, cylindrical worm that is typically iridescent brown or dark green in colour. Typical of members of this family the head has two pairs of small, dark eyes, two short tentacles, a pair of swollen palps each topped by a tiny nipple-like segment, and behind these 4 pairs of tentacle-like cirri. The segmental limbs (parapodia) are lobed and armed with two tufts of firm bristles.

There are numerous regional species in the group that can only really be definitively identified by everting the pharynx and examining the patterns of teeth on its surface (see cited references below as to how to do this), and by detailed examination of the setae and gills on the parapodia. This species is fairly distinctive though, due to its unusually large size and the fact that it is so abundant in mussel beds and Cape reefworm (Gunnarea gaimardi) colonies.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.

Large, active worm that is very common among mussels, reefworm colonies, kelp holdfasts and similar habitats, where it can reach considerable densities. When the pharynx is everted this bears a pair of formidable jaws terminally.

Commonly exploited as bait by fishers.
Omnivorous, feeding on other worms and smaller crustaceans, but also consuming seaweeds.
Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.

There are many similar species in the region and accurate identification of these requires microscopic examination of the everted pharynx and of the gills and setae on the parapodia. However, most related species are much smaller and more slender and hence large, robust worms (>50 mm), especially those found among mussels and reef-worm colonise, can fairly reliably be assigned to this species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1. (p. 331).

Kara, J, Macdonald, AH & Simon CA (2018). Integrative taxonomic methods reveal an incorrect synonymisation of the South African Pseudonereis podocirra (Schmarda) as the widespread Pseudonereis variegata (Grube) from Chile. Invertebrate Systematics, 32(6), 1282-1297.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
